column6: The original, operating website where the marketing model is sale of subscriptions to music teachers and schools, who in turn "sell" to students whose educational progress they manage
This will be operated "unchanged" during development of ComePlayMusic.com
The new website designed to market to individual families and students directly, as well as to schools and music teachers
A website providing learning exercises that teach to sing on pitch
A website providing retail sales of "Terry Treble" branded products designed as awards for musical performance, and cross-marketing of MLC and CPM
This might be incorporated into CPM
A website providing guided piano and music instruction for independent and teacher-guided students
PLL utilizes both the music games from MLC and additional functionality in support of piano teaching

column5: A discrete set of programmed procedures that teaches a concept in a game form.

column6: These are the primary learning elements.

column5: Games, videos, text, music, tasks, and other items predefined to be included in lesson assignments.

column6: "Game Elements" is used as a generalized term for a variety of presentations that can be made to a student, including games, videos, text, music, and tasks.
Non-game elements are called "supporting media elements".

column5: The alpha-numeric identification given to a specific game

column6: Game Concept Description (used for assignment label)
Associated with each Game Name is a brief description of less than 100 characters

column5: Each game has at least three and sometimes four stages through which the student advances

column6: "Learn stage" is a tutorial introducing the musical concept
"Play stage" is a set of routines for practicing, or "drill" of the concept
"Quiz stage" is a set of routines designed to test mastery of the concept by the student
"Challenge stage" is a set of routines associated with specific games that allows unlimited scoring and permits a student to compete with other students world-wide
All stages are available to a student, and are separate games, as marked by the stage parameter

column5: An internally-generated unique identifier for each unique game-stage combination

column6: For example, a game "Fun Notes" might have an internal number of 12120.  The stages could be numbered 1, 2, 3, and 4.  And the last digit position could be reserved for the stage.  So the number for Fun Notes Play would be 12122, and for the Fun Notes Challenge would be 12124.
Use of an internal number could avoid some difficulty of mis-spelled or ambiguous naming, and provides a built-in sequence for game ordering in a list.
The game number is combined with the Named Sequence number and Named Sequence Group number to create a Sequence Assignment code.
MIDI games have the same number as any non-MIDI equivalent, but all MIDI games have an "M" suffix

column5: Each game has a distinct (html) description page

column6: A moderately succinct description of what the game teaches and how it does this
These game descriptions are in the public area of the website and are searcheable (via Google)
A visitor finding a game description is led to a specific marketing page.

column5: A quantitive measure obtained by a student when completing a game--a quantitative measure of achievement

column6: Scores are obtained only when game is played to completion
Scores are recorded in the data base and observable by the student and teacher
Several scores are retained: date and score when first played; date and score when last played; date and highest score obtained.

Scores are presented in the student Assignment Box along side each game and color-highlighted; in green when the target score has been reached, in yellow when a 90% score has been reached, and in red when the score obtained is less than 90%.

column5: A pre-defined value for each game that if obtained by the student represents mastery of the concept being taught

column6: Achievement of a target score is a recorded event.
When the target score has been reached for all games in an Sequence Assignment Group the next Assignment Group is presented to the student

column5: A set of Concept Categories related to an area of education, e.g. music education, art education, language education
A set of definitions of concepts applicable to an area of eductation, i.e, "musical rythmn", "language tense"

column6: Every game has an assignment parameter set for every category

column5: A distinct subcategorization of an area concept, i.e., "music rhythm 4/4 time"

column6: Category Parameter - every game will be assigned a "null", "include", or "exclude" parameter for each category, indicating that the particular musical concept is represented in the game, or does not apply ("null" or "ignore").
The parameters of a concept category are universal across the categories, but the parameters used with Tier 1 and Tier 2 are uniquely defined, and tied to each category.
New parameters may be added only by the Content Administrator

column5: Levels of detail of  concept category parameters

column6: The parameters of concept category are universal across the categories, but the parameters used with Tier 1 and Tier 2 are uniquely defined, and tied to each category.
Category Tier 1- Most games will have one or more Tier 1 parameter assignments, indicating musical concept details being covered.

Category Tier 2 - These parameters are much more specific than Tier 1 and constitute the principal defining features used in sequencing. These wil be marked using Druple tags, rather than pre-definition
Most categories will not have Tier 2 parameters

column5: The order in which games are presented to students to play

column6: This order is determined by a combination of elements including:

Sequencing is primarily an assignment of a succession of concepts, which in turn results in presentation of games that support those concepts.  Said another way, the result is a selection of games to be played, but the mechanism by which this happens is a selection of a series of concepts.
Example of sequence of assignment groups:

column5: A game sequence organization which is directly related to a pre-established or published teaching method

column6: Music publishing companies have published series of piano teaching books, i.e. "Faber", "Alfred"
MLC incorporates its own "Lifetime Musician Curriculum"
These may be added only by the Content Administrator
Once created, a named game sequence is universally available
A sequence is unique by Name and Level.
Expectation is that the order of magnitude of number of named game sequences is under 100.

column5: The first sub-division of a Named Sequence

column6: Combined with Name, this creates a unique individual Named Sequence

column5: The second sub-division of a Named Sequence--sub-division of a Sequence Level

column6: This is additional sub-categorization of a level, to correlate with the external source materials.
Also available is a descriptive box which can hold other information, such as page number.
A student's initial sequence assignment must be defined at the "Sequence", "Level", "Unit" detail
This is used as the default for game category searches
This is the default for game assignments
Used as the curriculum for the PLL website
Is the basis for creation of a custom named game sequence

Every game is coded with a LMC sequence group number, which is the number of the Sequence Assignment Group in which the game first appears in the LMC sequence.  This number is used for automatic addition of new games to the already-established Named Sequences.

column5: A custom named game sequence created by a Teacher for use with his or her students by assignment

column6: A utility feature presents the details of the Lifetime Musician Curriculum sequence with all of its parameters selected
The teacher provides a new name for a custom curriculum, which in the background is associated directly with that teacher's profile, and may be used only by that teacher
The concept is that in the background this is simply a stored set of data base searches
Expectation is that the order of magnitude of number of custom game sequences is under 100 in total, with only one to four per teacher that uses the feature.

column5: The process of matching a named sequence to individual game concepts through selection of parameters
The abiity of a teacher or parent to assign a named sequence to a student
The ordered set of individual assignments of individual games and groups of games matching a Named Sequence

column6: When a sequence selection is made the entire sequence is assigned to a student, but for practical purposes the student needs to be given only pieces--sets of games--to learn and play for a period of time, before moving on to the next groups of games in the sequence.  These groups are the "homework assignments".
Assignment group codes are used to identify these sequence assignments.
The individual assignments order is retained.
A student's initial sequence assignment must be defined at the "Sequence", "Level", "Unit" detail

column5: A code assignment to a named sequence that splits the sequence into groups for assignment

column6: When a student enters their landing page the assignment that appears is the "current" assignment group
The code is a number that is assigned--the same number is assigned to each element that is to be in the same group.
The number may be a decimal, permitting insertion of a new group in between two previously established Sequence Assignment Groups without having to renumber all subsequent groups.

column5: An option to pre-set one Named Sequence to automatically follow another Named Sequence

column6: This is used to enable a teacher to tie a student to a Named Sequence and not have to repeat with successive sequences.
It is specifically used with the Lifetime Musician Curriculum, which is broken into several Named Sequences (by Level).

The code is set in the sequence intended to follow another one, by naming the preceding sequence.  The entry of data into this field activates the automated feature.  In the absence of this data when a Named Sequence is completed a student receives no further assignments  until the Teacher assigns another Named Sequence to the student.

column5: The administrative process of identifying with parameters the details of concepts taught by an individual game

column6: This process requires assigning parameters at the category, Tier 1 and Tier 2 levels, as many as needed to fully define the musical concepts involved.
This task is only performed by the Content Administrator

column5: Search for a game or group of games based upon the concepts being taught

column6: At minimum this search requires selection criteria to include at least one category
Can be performed by teacher, parent, or student
Marking additional selection criteria at the category level will narrow the search
The selection criteria are "and'ed", meaning an sql AND statement, where all selection criteria must be true to retrieve a data base selection.
The result of a search can be entered into the Custom Current Assignments box of a student profile, becoming part of the next assignment.

column5: Ordered set of learning elements focused on music learning games that teach individual concepts

column6: Correlated with external methods by a Sequence Name/Level/Unit & Description
Defined internally with a group number and a group level number
Title:  A general name for the assignment group
Sequence:  The name of the sequence (e.g., "Alfred Premier")
Level:  Generally a specific, such as "Level 1", but could be something else
Unit:  Often a specific unit, e.g. "Unit 1", but could be a book, e.g. "Book 3"
Synopsis:  Free-form text used to describe a summary of the assignment.

column5: The box on the screen visible to a student that includes the current game assignment

column6: The current assignments are in the order specified in the Sequence Group Assignment
The target scores and their level of achievement are listed next to the games
Custom assignments may be added to those automatically assigned.
The main assignment pane is broken into three sub-panes:
MIDI sequenced game assignments (with caption "You need a MIDI keyboard attached to play these")
Custom game assignments from the teacher

column5: Videos, text, music, awards, and other defined teaching elements can be categorized just as games

column6: These are used to prepare students for their assignments or to reinforce what has been learned.  They can also be used as a type of reward for completing the assignments.
Categorization of a supporting media element is accomplished in exactly the same fashion as a game, i.e. supporting media elements are a sub-category of games.

column5: Before the Assignment Pane a box provides learning activities or supporting media  including video, music, and text

column6: This is also called the "introduction pane"

column5: Following the Assignment Pane a box provides learning activities or supporting media to reinforce concepts just learned

column6: This is also called the "summary pane"

column5: Every subscriber has a unique number of variable length up to six digits.

column6: Users become members of "Music Learning Community", which provides access to all MLC sites.
This is used for discount identification purposes and referrals

column5: Non-subscribers who need to be identified with a relationship are provided a number identifier

column6: This is used for identification for commissions and other identification purposes.  Perhaps this is not needed--"associates" must become members as everyone else.

column5: Every signup process includes the option of filling in an associated code

column6: Structure is a letter prefix, a relationship code, optional coupon number  [ A-######-aaaaa]
Letter signifies a range or set of promotions
The relationship code is a Member Number or Associate Number
The coupon number is alphanumeric and defaults to zero if none is entered. First letter determines type of promotion.
A chart of promotion codes is provided in the system for their definition.
Spry Digital or other person or organization that has full access to the system.
Highest level of access to the management system exclusive of the base code.
Can perform any function of any other role.
There should be an administration dashboard for this level.
The member that has the ability to perform school administration functions for multiple schools.

The role permission is granted via the insert of the member number in the school grouping code of the school profile.  The role then takes on the same permissions as the School Administrator for each school having the same group number.  The group number can only be inserted by the School Administrator.
The member that has the ability to perform school administration functions
This user can act in the role of a Teacher
The member that has the ability to add and manage students
This role is the same whether under a school or private membership
The user receiving the benefit of the educational activities
A student is never a member, but is always associated with a Teacher or Family Head
The member that has the ability to perform the teacher functions.
A member having access to the system to manage their profile, but having no other role.
A non-member visitor to the website

column6: There are five domains/websites under consideration for branding and marketing purposes.

The conceptual framework is that both distinctions and commonalities are present.  Each website can be marketed to different segments and serve slightly different purposes, yet sharing the intellectual property and functionality.

This character is on almost all advertising material

MLC emphasizes support of music teachers, public school music programs, and their students
It is designed to be the repository of educational materials, a blog, and music community-related content.
The look and feel of the site reflects the solid educational experience within, but is not intimidating
CPM houses the music education content developed by MusicLearningCommunity.
The site has different areas to support fully music teachers and schools, but also attracts and engages the market of families, home schoolers, and others without music teacher guidance.
The look and feel of the site reflects the need to attract the general public to a non-threatening, fun, engaging, and rewarding musical experience.
CSM is aimed at all ages and does not require the CPM games
This specifically addresses teaching singing on pitch
Some semi-advanced singing technique education is also provided
Subscribers to CSM would probably get a discount on CPM subscriptions
PLL is aimed at support primarily of adult piano students, although non-threatening to children as well
Those interested in general music rather than piano-specific instruction would be directed to CPM
TT is a provider of music award products, other logo products, and supporting products for music education and entertainment.
The look and feel of the site is fun for kids but adults see the value
Discounts are provided to all members of MLC

column5: The primary competion consists of any other activity that occupies a student's time on and off the internet
There are only two websites targeting the same markets with music learning games

column6: This is from an Canadian company.
The games are well done, they have a large number of them.  The pedagogy is okay.
The teacher management is very complicated.
This is from a Japanese company which appears to have studied MLC and included similar features.
Unknown if there is a curriculum management system within.
This is from an American company, from a public school music teacher who has created these for her own students and shares them with everyone (from her website)
These inculde flash games and printable worksheets.
This company is offering mobile apps that are music games.  These are well done and engaging.
Scoring available to teachers is missing.
Only a relatively few games have been produced.
The business model is economically questionable, but the developer owns his own software company,
One has to pay for each game one-time at download.

column5: Many music-type apps are available on the iPad

column6: These generally deal with only a few concepts, but some are very good. (e.g. Rolf's Rhythm)
Obviously these lack a coordinated, systematic curriculum for learning.

Most of this game creation process takes place external to the website and then the finished game is added to the system.  This specification deals with the addtion to the system of a game not currently present.
The game is established, then added to the LMC Sequence, then added to all other sequences.
Supporting media elements such as videos, music, and text are included in the general defintion of game.

column5: Naming the game in the data base
Adding the game to the website from the development environment
Connecting the game to the name, and establishing the game number
Using the standard functionality, the Lifetime Musician Curriculum Sequence is brought up for edit
Using the search function, the Inactive new game is selected
The new game is then dragged and dropped to the determined Sequence Assignment group of LMC
The group number is noted, and then:
The game is edited to add the LMC Group Number to the game.

column4: Steps to add to all Named Sequences
column6:
{This is being delayed until Phase V or later}  Updated 09-11-12
Instead of an automatic process, a report will be used to identify where the LMC Group number of the new game appears in each existing sequence.  Using this report as a guide the new game wil be manually added to each sequence.

column5: Access the special function for adding to Named Sequences
Select the game to be added to all of the Named Sequences

column6: The process will recognize the LMC Sequence Group number of the new game
Successively every existing Named Sequence (other than LMC) will be reviewed
For each Named Sequence a search will proceed to find the first Assignment Group that has a game assigned with the LMC Sequence Group number being queried.
Upon finding the group containing the game with the matching LMC Assignment Group number, the new game will automatically be entered into the same Assignment Group code
If the LMC Sequence Group number is not found in any Named Sequence, the new game will not be added to that sequence.
Custom Named Sequences are not included in the automated process

column5: Any Named Sequence can be edited and games moved to different Sequence Assignment Groups

column6: This process provides the basis for automatically presenting to a student game assignments in a prescribed order associated with an external or custom teaching method (Named Sequence).  The order will be Level-Unit-Group Code

This code, a decimal number, identifies the group of concepts aligned with the Level-Unit combination.  A group code can either split or group elements of a named sequence.

column6: The process is designed to minimize the possibilities that a user will search for a non-existent combination

From the retrieved set the user may select the one desired and play it.

column5: The logic of the search needs to be made simple so that the user can combine "and" and "or" selection criteria

column6: The default situation is "And", where the game retrieved must match all of the selected conditions, i.e. if both Major and Minor Chords are selected the retrieved games must include both Major and Minor.
If a user wanted to find games that included Major "Or" Minor, then some change in the search parameters must be made.

In many cases simple selection of only the Tier 1 parameters will be sufficient to find a set of games that meet the need for the "Or" condition, but Chords is a good counter-example, since Major and Minor are Tier 1 parameters and the resultant set will be comparatively very large

User Roles.  There are three user levels: Administrator, Teacher/Classroom, and Student.  These correspond to distinct roles within the system, having different access to the learning system and website functions.

School Membership.  Membership by the school in MusicLearningCommunity.com is a requirement.  This subscription is free.  Upon creating the membership the type of membership (School) is selected, and the Administrator is named.  If the Administrator personally is a member, that membership is not used for the school.  Billing is related to member number and grouping.  All payments are made to MusicLearningCommunity.com, LLC.

Grouping.  It is also possible to group schools together within a district for volume pricing, since school subscriptions are based upon the number of students who will be accessing the system.  This grouping may be done at any time.  For example, one school might become a member and then, based upon seeing the successful results from that program other schools in the district might want subscriptions.  At that point multiple schools may be grouped together to get the best pricing for all.  There is no pricing benefit by grouping unless the minimum total of 1350 student slots are reserved.

District Membership.  Grouping schools together is done via a district membership in MusicLearningCommunity.com.  (This can also be used to group multiple products together, e.g. ComePlayMusic.com and ComeSingMusic.com).  When the membership is created the member type District is selected.  An Administrator for the District must be named.  That person may be distinct or could be the same person as one of the Schools.  Billing information for the district needs to be entered

School Administrator.  This is the person who will administer the system for the school.  If multiple schools are involved, there must be an administrator named for each school, although the same person could be assigned to each of these roles. Often the School Administrator is the music teacher. The School Administrator adds Teacher/Classrooms to the system and connects students with Teacher/Classrooms.  This role also supervises the automated upload of students.  The School Administrator can set up a Teacher username and password so that he or she can act in the Teacher role as well.

Teacher/Classroom.  There is no limit to the number of Teacher/Classrooms that can be set up.  The subscription limits are on the number of student usernames.  The role can be named with an individual teacher name, a class name, or combination.  For example, SmithJMWF might mean John Smiths class Monday, Wednesday, Friday; or 4JSmith might represent John Smith Fourth Grade.  Generally the system documentation will refer to Teacher for this role.

The Teacher may define student usernames and passwords, monitor student score reports, and make both automated and custom assignments.  A Teacher only sees the students that he or she has defined, or those that have been automatically uploaded to his or her Teacher/Classroom role.

There are two primary options on how the learning system can be used; (1) Lab with generic usernames, (2) Individual students.  In the first scenario the annual subscription limited to 50 students is most frequently used.  This provides 50 user slots for use.  The Teacher defines generic usernames and passwords for these slots, such as CPMX01, CPMX02, UserJJK1, UserJJK2, UserJJK50, for example, and then simple passwords such as tune, music, etc.  (Note that the username must be unique among the worldwide users of ComePlayMusic).  The learning system is then used in a lab situation, each student signing in with one of the 50 users.  Although scores are obtained upon completing a game, the individual student score-keeping function is really not being used for student progress tracking, as multiple students are using the same logon credentials.

In the second scenario the individual student is set up with his or her own unique username and password.  Their game scores are retained, automatic awards are given for completion of assignments, and they can compete in the world-wide competition with Challenge-level games.  And the students can play their game assignments at home or wherever they have internet access.

Student.  The student role can log in to the system using the unique username and password assigned to them.  They can then automatically be presented with their assignment, following a pre-established curriculum, play the games, and see their scores.  They have access to an Recognition Board where they can see the awards earned.  Depending upon the schools choices, the student can access the system only from the school lab or from most devices having internet access from school or home.

Pricing.  A school subscription is based upon the number of student slots being reserved for student access and is an annual subscription for the school year with no charge for the summer months.  Pricing is per school unless there is a district member, the schools are grouped using that member number, and the minimum total students of 1350 is reached.  In that case all schools have the same lowest price for the total number of student slots reserved. For access to the games that use a MIDI keyboard the cost is $30.00 per school annually, and there are no applicable discounts.

Adding & Deleting Student Slots.  This function may be performed by the School Administrator.  More student slots may be reserved at any time, but there is no proration based upon the date added.  If the number of student slots is reduced, there is no rebate during the billing cycle.  The automatic renewal will use the number of reserved student slots in effect at the end of the billing cycle as the basis for the renewal bill.  Administrators should be cautioned that adding reserved student slots has an immediate financial impact.

Billing.  At the time the beginning subscription is initiated online, the number of student slots to reserve is requested.  That number is used in the pricing schedule and an invoice is automatically generated and e-mailed to the school contact.  For example, if the need is to reserve space for 470 students the price calculated would be $680 for 400 plus $127.50 for an additional 75 ($42.50 x 25 X 3), for a total of $807.50.  In this case it would probably be better to subscribe for 500 students, since the price for 500 is $825.

Once the invoice has been generated the account is in a pending status until receipt of payment.  However, during this period the website is fully accessible by the member administrator, teachers, and students.  Payment in full is expected within 30 days of the invoice.

Renewal Billing. The School Administrator needs to enter the billing cycle renewal date in the account management profile for the system to use to coordinate billing dates with the school year processes.  It is assumed that the school will wish to continue with its subscription.  The renewal date entered by the Administrator is only month and dayno year is required.  This date is picked up each year and an invoice automatically created and sent 30 days prior to that date, based upon the profile that exists as of the renewal date, that is the number of students, addresses, contacts, purchase order number, etc.
Upon receiving a renewal invoice if the school does not wish to continue the subscription the Administrator need only go to the account management profile and select the suspend or cancel option.

Purchase Orders.  MusicLearningCommunity.com LLC does not require purchase orders, as all functions can be performed fully on-line.  There is a field in the member account management profile for the School Administrator to enter a purchase order number if needed by the school.  This number will be picked up in the automated billing process and will display on the invoice.

If a purchase order is sent to MusicLearningCommunity.com, an e-mail response will be sent to the contact with instructions for accessing the website to set up the member profile and start the subscription process.  Invoices will then be generated in the normal manner.

Student Lessons are presented as sequential organized groups of learning elements, where each group is an Assignment.  The sequence in which these Assignments are presented is directly correlated to an external piano method, state curriculum, or other specifically Named Sequence of teaching musical concepts.

Automatic Presentation.  Once the specific sequence has been given to an individual student (in the student management area), when the student logs in to his or her Student Lessons the next Assignment in the sequence is automatically presented.  A student is expected to complete all of the elements of an Assignment before moving to the next one, which will be automatically presented.

Sequence Naming.  To tie the external sequence to the internal assignment group an organizational naming convention is used.  The external sequence is identified with a Sequence Name.  Then it is broken down into Sequence Levels (often corresponding to a single method book).  Finally these levels are broken down in sections called Sequence Units.  The concepts taught in a single Sequence/Level/Unit are then presented to the student as one or more Assignment Groups (Assignment).

Assignment Groups.  An Assignment group consists of an ordered set of learning elements (including video, text, music, awards, and games), focused on music learning games that teach the individual concepts.  Each Assignment group, when originally defined by the Content Administrator, includes some additional internal information used to help manage the learning system. Such internal information includes group number and group level.

Panes.  This Assignment set or group is presented in three sequential parts; an introduction or preview pane, a main assignment pane (the games), and a summary pane.  The main assignment pane is actually split into three sub-panes, where the first holds the automatic non-MIDI game assignments, the second holds automatic MIDI game assignments, and the third holds any additional games specifically assigned by the teacher.

Pane Appearing.  The introduction pane appears first and the other panes are not available until this first pane is completed.  Then the main pane appears.  When the first two panes are completed the last pane appears.  The summary pane may include awards, challenge games, or other learning elements, including audio files.  A quiz review, which is the presentation of a previously mastered games quiz stage to verify that a student has retained his or her mastery of the concept, may appear in the main assignment pane.

Game Stages.  When learning games are presented the learn, play, and quiz stages of each game are all included.  A student is permitted to skip to the quiz stage, and if a target score is reached at that stage, the learn and play stages are considered to have been completed.  The challenge stage of the game will appear in the third pane.

Remediation.  If a student has played only the quiz stage and has not reached the target score after 5 tries, then the student is automatically presented with the learn stage game.  If the student plays the learn, play, and quiz stages and has not reached the target score after 5 tries, a notice is automatically sent to the teacher or family administrator of that fact.

MIDI games.  Certain games are configured to utilize a MIDI keyboard attached to the computer used to play the games.  These games cannot be played on a mobile device.  Nor can they be played if the student does not have a MIDI keyboard.  In many cases there is a corresponding non-MIDI game.  These games are defined in any sequence for which they are applicable, but should not appear for a student unless the MIDI subscription is enabled. Each set of MIDI and non-MIDI games will have the same game number, but the MIDI will have a letter suffix of M.

MIDI Completion.  What is needed is a way to present MIDI games and to evaluate completion of student assignments.  If the teacher has a subscription to the MIDI games but the student does not have access to a MIDI device, then we do not want the student blocked from being able to proceed.

MIDI Sub-pane.  A suggested approach is to add a MIDI sub-pane to the Assignment Group, indicating that these games require a MIDI keyboard to be attached.  If there is a MIDI subscription these games would appear in the pane and would need to be played for completion.  Non-MIDI games for which there was an equivalent MIDI game (same base game number) would not appear in the main assignment pane.

MIDI Suppression.  The teacher, at the time of defining the starting named sequence for a student, would also mark if MIDI is to be suppressed.  The default is that if the teacher has a MIDI subscription, the student would automatically get the MIDI games, but the teacher could override this and no MIDI games would appear in the assignment.

At any time a teacher has the ability to look at an individual student assignment and mark that individual games are completed, regardless of student score.  When a teacher performs this override the student becomes entitled to execute whatever is in the summary pane, and receives any awards there.
The teacher needs the ability to manage a student with some degree of detail, without requiring the teacher to do so.

[Another approach to MIDI game presentation might be that designation of completion of an assignment is the same as without MIDI games, but if at least one of the MIDI games is played, then the remainder of them must be played in order to complete the assignment.  The logic being that if one game is played, then a MIDI device is available.  We do not think this works as well as what is presented above.]

Game Playing.  Outside of his or her lessons, (student recess) a student is permitted access to all games, with the exception of the quiz stage games, in his or her current level.  They are also provided an easy way to return to any games previously played in their completed lessons.

Internal Group Level.  Every student lesson assignment includes in its definition an internal group level (a number 0-7).  This internal group level is set by the Content Administrator when the assignment group is defined.  (It is based upon general pedagogy and expertise.)

Game Level Range.  Every game is defined to include an internal level range parameter. For example, a game might have an internal level range of 1-3.  This means that the game might be used in more than one group level, specifically 1, 2, or 3.  This level range relates to the Sequence Level, but, since external methodologies have a variety of nomenclature, the definition of this level range aids in standardization within the learning system.
Level Comparison.  So the system can make a comparison between the internal group level of the students current assignment, or just completed, and the internal level range of any game.

Limited to Current Level.  A student is not permitted to play games where the games defined internal level range does not include the internal group level currently assigned to him or her.  For example, if a students current Assignment is in primary level (internal group level = 0), he or she will not be permitted to select and play on their own any games defined to have a level range with the minimum higher than primary level, such as 1-2.
This level limitation may be overridden by the teacher in the student's profile

Lesson Skipping.  A student is allowed to return to previous lesson Assignments by skipping backwards sequentially and repeating any part, or all parts, of an Assignment group.  A student is also allowed to skip forward to the next Assignments, sequentially, even though the current lesson assignment is incomplete.  This skipping is allowed, even if the next lesson assignment has a higher internal level.

Level Persistence.  However, when a student logs in to the system again, he or she is presented with the first lesson in their assigned sequence that has not been completed.  Additionally, even if the student has skipped to a lesson that has a higher internal level than the assigned lesson that is incomplete, the student is considered to still be at the level of the incomplete assignment, and therefore at recess cannot play any games above that level.

Controlled Flexibility.  So students have some flexibility to move forward with Assignments, and they can play a variety of games, but there is still significant incentive to complete assignments so that they get the awards, can play challenge games, and can play higher level games during recess.

Assessment Sequences.  Specific named sequences are provided to teachers to assign to new students for the purpose of assessing their degree of mastery of music concepts.  These sequences are related to internal level ranges and constitute only the quiz games for those levels.  These are organized in such a way that the scoring results from the students completion indicates at what level they should begin Assignments.
Beginning Level Assignment.  The individual teacher or family administrator may assign a starting position above or below, but the assessment (or pre-test) is a good indicator.

[Probably the way this will be implemented is to present to the teacher or family administrator a report of the scores from the completion of the assessment sequence in the same manner as any other assigned sequence.  Certain totals (yet to be defined) will be presented (to eliminate the need for the teacher to manually perform the calculations).  A separate evaluation algorithm will be presented to the teacher or family administrator, which they can use to arrive at a predicted starting level.  Since we have no actual results from such an algorithm to date we do not want to build in that automation at this time.  In the future we may be able to provide a fully-automated level-assigning pre-test.]
